issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify a method addGuestStudents(int) (single int parameter). The template, however, declares addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) with an extra boolean parameter. The solution implements the single-parameter signature addGuestStudents(int). This parameter mismatch is structural: students following the template will produce a method signature that doesn't match the specification/tests (or be unsure which signature to implement), causing compilation/test failures or confusion about the intended API.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template method signature to match the specification: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { /* TODO: implement and validate input internally if desired */ }. Alternatively, provide the single-argument method expected by the exercise and, if input validation with a flag is desired for other purposes, add an overloaded helper method (e.g. addGuestStudents(int, boolean)) that delegates to the single-arg API. Ensure method name and parameters match the problem statement and the solution.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify a method addGuestStudents(int) but the template repository provides a different signature: addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput). The solution implements addGuestStudents(int). This signature mismatch (extra boolean parameter) breaks the one-to-one mapping between the task description and the starter code, will confuse students about which method to implement/use, and may cause tests or example usage to fail because the expected single-parameter method is not present in the template.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template's method signature to match the problem statement and solution: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { ... }. If input validation is desired, either implement it internally within this single-parameter method or provide an additional overloaded method (e.g., addGuestStudents(int, boolean)) while keeping the single-parameter variant as the primary API expected by the exercise and tests.
